translatedTitle: Get ready for congruence, similarity, and triangle trigonometry
translatedDescription: In this unit, we'll focus on understanding congruence and similarity, and how these concepts can be used to compare shapes. We'll also tackle the Pythagorean theorem and triangle trigonometry, so get ready to sharpen those pencils!

translatedDescription: What do architects, graphic designers, and engineers all have in common? They use analytic geometry! In this unit of study, you'll learn the basics of using math to create precise drawings and models.

translatedDescription: This unit lays the groundwork for understanding conic geometry. By covering basic concepts and definitions, it sets the stage for exploring the properties and applications of various shapes such as circles, ellipses, parabolas, and hyperbolas.

translatedTitle: Get ready for circles and solid geometry
translatedDescription: In this unit, we're circling back to one of the most fundamental shapes in geometry: the circle! We'll talk radius, diameter, circumference, and area, and even take a bite out of "pie" to get a full understanding.

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Get ready for circles and solid geometry: Quiz 1
allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Volume and surface area word problems

translatedDescription: How does the way computers process information differ from how humans process information? Learn how computers interpret sequence and state as you write, run, and debug your first Python programs. Explore data types, operators, and variables, and learn how to make your programs interactive with user input.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Meet the Python programming environment.
What happens when you run a program?
Let's remember this for later.
Computers can do math faster than humans, so why not let them?
The Internet is made of strings.
Review the syntax for this unit.

translatedDescription: Can computers be objective decision makers? Discover selection as you design algorithms that allow the computer to decide which code to run and when. Learn how to evaluate boolean expressions and construct conditionals to add branching logic to your programs.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: What if you only want to do some things some of the time?
True or False? George Boole knows!
You come to a fork in the road: if, elif, else. Which path do you take?
Can you put a conditional inside a conditional?
How do recommendation engines know what to recommend?
Review the syntax for this unit.

translatedDescription: How can you use computers to predict outcomes that are too big for humans to calculate? Discover repetition with while loops and for loops with range. Learn how to simulate events over time by setting up experiments with randomness and repeating them with loops.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Why reinvent the wheel when you can import wheel?
Control flow isn't always linear. Sometimes, it loops!
For when you know the number of times you want to repeat.
Can you terminate a loop under several conditions?
How can you design an experiment to simulate natural selection?
Review the syntax for this unit.

translatedDescription: How do teams of programmers continuously write and revise code without breaking things? Learn how to break down programs into smaller, independent functions that can be easily read, reused, and tested. Design and write function definitions with parameters and return values as you develop your own game components.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Can you break down a program into smaller pieces?
What happens when a function calls another function?
An organized programmer is a happy programmer.
How can you be sure that your function works?
Players have short attention spans. Can you keep them engaged?
Review the syntax for this unit.

translatedDescription: How can programs make your life easier? Discover how to store multiple values in a list, so that you can process data quickly and efficiently. Learn how to index into and iterate over Python sequences as you write scripts to automate tedious tasks.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: How does a programmer count to 3? ...0, 1, 2.
Looping over lists.
Don't go changing; strings are immutable.
Append at the end, insert in the middle.
Review the syntax for this unit.

translatedDescription: How can you use programming to make sense of large amounts of data, and apply those insights to guide real world actions? Learn how to use dictionaries to organize your data into key-value pairs for easy lookup. Consider the tradeoffs of different data structures in common data science problems.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: The key to dictionaries is keys and values.
Choose your own adventure: by key, by value, or by key-value.
Can you put a list inside of a dictionary?
Looping layer by layer.
Review the syntax for this unit.

translatedDescription: Supplemental videos used in this course.

This unit will take you on a fascinating journey through the world of cells and organisms. You'll get an up-close look at plant and animal cells, learn about organelles, explore the organization of the human body, and gain a deeper understanding of sensory processing and the brain.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: 30 trillion cells in a trench coat walks into a movie theater. "One ticket please."
Every cell is a like a miniature organism, where every piece has an essential role to play.
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
The liver bone's connected to the pancreas bone. Wait. Those aren't bones!
How do you feel? No, literally, how do you feel and perceive things?
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Test your understanding of {unit name}.

translatedDescription: Let's learn how organisms grow and make more of themselves! Whether it's through sexual or asexual reproduction, there's a lot to learn about what makes for success, and how genes and the environment come into play.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Did you know that a detached starfish arm can grow into a whole new starfish?
I've got one word for you: PLUMAGE.
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Hummingbirds, ants, and bats: what do these animals have in common? They're all pollinators!
Plants and animals are programmed by their genes to grow to a specific size range, but external factors matter, too.
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Organism growth and reproduction: Unit test
allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Test your understanding of {unit name}.

translatedDescription: Let's explore the secret lives of organisms! This unit will reveal how living things harness matter and energy for survival through incredible processes like photosynthesis and cellular respiration.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Take a deep breath. Thank a plant.

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Matter and energy in organisms: Quiz 1
allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
How does a piece of pizza get from your mouth to your muscles?

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Matter and energy in organisms: Quiz 2
allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Activity: How can measuring cellular respiration help us reach a fitness goal?
allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Make science come alive in your classroom with this free hands-on activity aligned to middle school NGSS standards.

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Matter and energy in organisms: Unit test
allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Test your understanding of {unit name}.

translatedDescription: Explore the wild world of ecosystems! From population growth to resource availability, you'll discover the fascinating ways that living things interact to create vibrant and diverse communities.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: It takes a village to be a forest.
Siri: define "zero-sum game".
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
"Friendship" is not the word I'd use to describe the shark-remora relationship, but "mutualism" is.
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Test your understanding of {unit name}.

translatedDescription: This unit explores how matter and energy keep ecosystems humming! Learn about the role of photosynthesis in ecosystems, and explore how food webs keep communities connected and thriving.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Did you know that all of the energy in an ecosystem can be traced back to the sun?
It's an owl-eat-frog-eat-grasshopper world out there.

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Activity: What happens when a food web is disturbed?
allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Make science come alive in your classroom with this free hands-on activity aligned to middle school NGSS standards.

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Matter and energy in ecosystems: Unit test
allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Test your understanding of {unit name}.

translatedDescription: Why is biodiversity is so important? In this unit, you'll explore ecosystem dynamics and learn about the benefits humans get from healthy and diverse ecosystems.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Imagine eating at the same restaurant every day, and one day the restaurant disappears. Now imagine how pandas feel when the bamboo grove they eat at is gone!
Flies are annoying, but what would happen if they suddenly disappeared?
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

"Everything depends on our ability to sustainably inhabit this earth and true sustainability will require us all to change our way of thinking on how we take from the earth and how we can give back." — Deb Haaland, Secretary of the Interior
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Test your understanding of {unit name}.

translatedDescription: How do the instructions in genes create the unique traits that we see in every living thing? Learn about how genes work, how they get passed from parent to offspring, and why most living things are genetically unique.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Have we got some special traits for you in this lesson!
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Which gene controls the "unbelievably charming" trait? And why do I have so many of 'em?
MUTANTS ARE AMONG US. Like cold viruses and corn and stuff.

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Activity: Why do some mutations cause genetic disorders?
allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Make science come alive in your classroom with this free hands-on activity aligned to middle school NGSS standards.
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
While you played four square, I studied the Punnett square.
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Test your understanding of {unit name}.

translatedDescription: Archaeopteryx, woolly mammoths, and saber-toothed cats, oh my! In this unit on evolution, you'll explore the fossil record, learn how to decipher evolutionary trees, and discover how organisms' physical traits provide evidence for evolution.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Did you know you are related to all living things on Earth?
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Yes, chicken, your ancestors were fearsome predators!
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Why do whale flipper-bones have fingers?
If you think all babies look the same, wait until you look at embryos.
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Test your understanding of {unit name}.

translatedDescription: In this unit, you'll learn all about the fascinating processes of natural and artificial selection. Discover the key roles that adaptation and environmental change play in shaping how species evolve over time.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Why isn't a zebra's neck as long as a giraffe's?
Okay, imagine some finches.
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Let's talk about goldendoodles.

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Natural and artificial selection: Unit test
allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Test your understanding of {unit name}.

translatedDescription: Make science come alive in your classroom with these free hands-on activities aligned to middle school NGSS standards.

Explore ancient art by focusing on specific objects: the Medusa mirror, the bust of an arrogant emperor, a vase and throne decorated with battle stories, a luxurious stag-shaped cup, and more. You’ll gain insights into history and artistry through short lessons and activities. Topics include Roman emperors, Greek myths, Persian craftsmanship, and how stories were told through illustrations and design.

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: An ancient portrait bust and propaganda
An ancient Greek sculpture of a musician
Functional art from the ancient world and today
Design & storytelling in an ancient vessel

translatedDescription: Greek vases with stories to tell, ancient glass and carved marble, Roman silver and exotic gems—explore the artistry and history of precious antiquities.

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Marble from antiquity to modern times

translatedDescription: Learn about some of the very first photographic techniques, and discover photographs of the early 1800s to the present. Hear artists discuss their images and processes.

translatedTitle: Welcome to the world of biodiversity!
translatedDescription: Take an expedition with us to investigate the amazing diversity of life on this planet. Learn what biodiversity is, why it is important, where it is found, how it comes into existence, how you study it, why it is threatened, and how it can be protected.
Discover why a high diversity of species sustains ecosystems, which in turn provide important services to humans.

Explore how life is found almost everywhere on Earth, but is not distributed evenly. And learn why the clumped distributions of species are the result of a wide variety of both natural and human-driven factors.
Delve into the history of humanity’s passion to document and display specimens from the natural world and learn how biodiversity expeditions are conducted today.
Examine the local and global threats to biodiversity that are caused by human activities. Many of the negative impacts start as regional, but easily add up to affect the entire planet.
Discover the wealth of options available in the vital race to protect biodiversity.

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Harnessing science and education for biodiversity conservation

translatedDescription: Earth's amazing diversity of life is the result of billions of years of evolution, of natural selection acting on individual genetic variation.

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Biodiversity patterns of speciation and extinction

translatedTitle: What are the different levels of biodiversity?
translatedDescription: Learn how to recognize the genetic, ecosystem, and evolutionary levels of biodiversity.  Along with species richness, these levels play crucial roles in conservation.

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Biodiversity and the tree of life

translatedDescription: The basic principles of music are explained in plain language with helpful graphics and live video demonstrations. If you have ever wondered “How does music work?” then you’ll find answers here. Presented by the All-Star Orchestra music director Gerard Schwarz.

Learn about band instruments from expert musicians with the United States Marine Band.  Lessons include warm-ups, excerpts, and helpful advice.  Established by an Act of Congress in 1798, the United States Marine Band is America’s oldest continuously active professional musical organization. The Marine Band performs at the White House an average of 200 times each year, and also presents annually an indoor concert series, summer concerts on the National Mall, and a national concert tour.

Discover what makes a masterpiece by learning how classical works are composed. Music Director Gerard Schwarz explains the history, context and compositional techniques behind famous orchestral works, from Beethoven to leading composers of the present day.

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Antonín Dvořák: Symphony No. 9 "From the New World"
Igor Stravinsky: Suite from The Firebird
Maurice Ravel: Suite No. 2 from Daphnis et Chloe
Augusta Read Thomas: Of Paradise and Light
Richard Danielpour: Piano Concerto No. 4, Movement III

translatedDescription: Learn about the different instruments of the orchestra as they are presented and demonstrated by  principal players from famous symphony orchestras.
Welcome to NASA Mission control, an introduction to the learning and exploration adventures offered in cooperation between NASA and Khan Academy!
How have we applied science and mathematics to understand our solar system?
Centuries of observations ignited curiosity about other bodies in our solar system. Eventually, we reached out and touched them...what did we find?

This unit on algebra foundations will introduce us to the exciting world of solving problems with variables! We'll learn about the history of algebra, what variables are, and how to work with them. From substitution to combining like terms, we'll gain the skills we need to take our math skills to the next level. Just let's watch out for that pesky division by zero!

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

translatedDescription: In this unit, we learn how to solve linear equations and inequalities that contain a single variable. For example, we'll solve equations like 2(x+3)=(4x-1)/2+7 and inequalities like 5x-2≥2(x-1).

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Linear equations with variables on both sides

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

translatedDescription: In this unit, we start to think about some general modeling concerns before we dive into modeling situations with different kinds of functions and equations throughout the course.

translatedDescription: In this unit, we'll dive into the world of linear equations and graphs. We'll learn about slope, intercepts, and the secrets to drawing perfectly straight lines. As we progress, we'll develop the skills to analyze and create all kinds of linear equations with ease!

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

translatedDescription: Slopes, points, intercepts, equations - all can provide clues about how to graph a line. In this unit, we learn how to write linear equations in different forms to reveal different features of their relationships.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

translatedDescription: How can we use two equations to find out the value of something? In this unit, we learn how to write systems of equations, solve those systems, and interpret what those solutions mean.

translatedDescription: In this unit, we study inequalities like x+2y>5 and graph them. This helps us see their solutions. We also explore systems of inequalities (multiple inequalities at the same time) and use them to describe real-world situations.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

translatedDescription: In this unit, we learn about functions, which are mathematical entities that assign unique outputs to given inputs. We'll evaluate, graph, analyze, and create various types of functions.

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Inputs and outputs of a function

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Introduction to the domain and range of a function

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Determining the domain of a function

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Intervals where a function is positive, negative, increasing, or decreasing

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

translatedDescription: In this unit, you'll get to learn all about scatterplots! We'll learn how to create them, and how to interpret all those funky looking dots. Plus, we'll learn how to use trend lines to make some pretty good guesses about data we don't even have. Who knew statistics could be so much fun?

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Test your understanding of {unit name}.

translatedDescription: In this unit, we'll dive into understanding data distributions. We'll learn about different ways to display data, how to summarize the center of a distribution, and how to compare distributions to one another. We'll explore charts, box and whisker plots, and more. With plenty of interesting concepts to learn, we're sure to have a good time!

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Test your understanding of {unit name}.

translatedDescription: This unit is all about two-way tables – those handy charts that can help us make sense of a bunch of data all at once! We'll learn how to read them, create them, and even take things up a notch by analyzing relative frequency tables. By the end of the unit, we'll be a two-way table whiz!

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Test your understanding of {unit name}.

translatedDescription: In this unit, we learn about the various ways in which we can define sequences. We'll construct arithmetic and geometric sequences to describe patterns and use those sequences to solve problems.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Test your understanding of {unit name}.

translatedDescription: In this unit, we review exponent rules and learn about higher-order roots like the cube root (or 3rd root). We'll learn how to calculate these roots and simplify algebraic expressions with radicals.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

translatedDescription: In this unit, we'll tackle exponential growth and decay. We'll explore the key differences between exponential and linear growth, and get plenty of practice with exponential expressions. As we delve into graphs and tables, we'll start to see patterns and understand how to model these changes ourselves. By the end, we'll all be experts in exponential growth!

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Exponential vs. linear growth over time

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

translatedDescription: In this topic, we will learn about the most useful math concept for creating video game graphics: geometric transformations, specifically translations, rotations, reflections, and dilations. We will learn how to perform the transformations, and how to map one figure into another using these transformations.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

translatedDescription: In this unit, we'll dive into the wild world of shape transformations! We'll explore all the different ways we can stretch, shrink, or move shapes around, while still keeping some key properties the same. We'll also learn how to use these transformations as tools in mathematical proofs. Let's get ready to transform our math skills!

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

translatedDescription: Learn what it means for two figures to be congruent, and how to determine whether two figures are congruent or not. Use this immensely important concept to prove various geometric theorems about triangles and parallelograms.

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Proofs of general theorems that use triangle congruence

translatedDescription: In analytic geometry, also known as coordinate geometry, we think about geometric objects on the coordinate plane. For example, we can see that opposite sides of a parallelogram are parallel by writing a linear equation for each side and seeing that the slopes are the same.
